Overall: 10/10\n
Sword Art Online: Alicization is in my eyes a masterpiece of entertainment , an all time classic and an easy 10 out of 10\n\n\n

First of all I want to tell why I gave SAO:Alicization - 10/10 because of the music and art which is the most notice able thing of any anime without it - it is just a manga.
-- Bad audience of SAO --
I always see people arguing about SAO but when season Alicization came I thought perhaps now people should watch that season and should give it a good rating but no! Selfish people are still selfish they always point out the bad facts and figures in everything they don't see good things in them because they don't have eyes to see or don't have aheart to understand it. It's like they have been given a duty to point out many bad facts as they can so they will be rewarded for completing the job.


SAO Alicization:


1. Art: The art of SAO is always been good if we talk about SAO's previous seasons according to there airing time as compare to other anime.

Perhaps (I said "perhaps" because Shingeki no Kyojin's art has a match for SAO.) the best anime as for the art in currently airing anime. The light effects with the peaceful scenery always feels good by watching it. The art of SAO: Alicization feels kind of real.


2. Sound: The soundtracks and songs of SAO are always good and always be good.

A. Songs:

The first time when I watch SAO: Alicization's first opening it wasn't impressive for me but as the time pass the episodes passed, hearing it again and again finally I loved it, so as for generally speaking I say the song rating should be 7-8/10 (but for me the song rating is 10/10). When the second opening came I didn't even liked it just because I was sad that first opening is gone (I know who are reading should say, "is that even a reason?") but that's not it! When that version of the second opening in the Episode 21 came I was like, "Which is the best opening of Alicization opening 1 or 2??" it is funny for me now when ever I think about it. As for the endings both are my favorites from the first day because it is based on Eugeo's tragic life and I love his story (I mean the story of Eugeo who passes through suffering and the pain of injustice found a person who taught him to fight for your people you love).

B. Soundtracks:

The soundtracks are one of the biggest reason why I always give SAO 10/10. Here I specially want to mention the Episode 16 of SAO: Alicization when Kirito and Eugeo fight against Alice at the "Cloudtop Garden" that time the soundtracks are insanely settled with the epic scene or should I say the most coolest scene of SAO: Alicization so far.

And also the sad musics which touches the heart in order to understand the situation in the scenes which I think can only be in great creations.


3. Story:

The story of Alicization shows a new game which is very different from the previous games in SAO series. In this game when a person dive in he/she becomes totally disconnected from the real world like he/she is in a dream (so we can say the Project Alicization is a project is to make a dream game) which is very interesting for me at-least because I am a gamer and a programmer of AI. If you heared the name of a story ALICE in wonderland (A Disney movie is also made on this story and it is one of my most favorite Disney movie since my childhood) you wil see the resemblance in there. SAO Alicization's story is mainly based on Eugeo's life how he lost ALICE in an accident and then found Kirito to help him to bring her back. And as for Kirito he always been in trouble and helping different people. Now Kirito is helping Eugeo, and why exactly he is helping Eugeo is to get information about the game to get out of there, but as the time passed he is getting more in the game and forgetting his real purpose and that is because of some people specially Eugeo and ALICE.


4. Characters:

The two new characters ALICE and Eugeo are very very good. ALICE and Eugeo who supposed to be like AI fluctlights have a mind like real humans. Other characters in Alicization are 

very good but not so impressive.

A. ALICE:

ALICE is my most favorite character of Alicization and the SAO series (you can see her in my top 10 character list) so far because her personality is very impressive the way she talk, the getup, the fighting style, her weapon (Osmanthus blade), her spirit and thoughts and everything about her is as is should be. ALICE is shown over powered and I like that fact that she is over powered. The reason why I think she should be over powered because we don't have any over powered characters since the first season of SAO. But some audience of SAO: Alicization doesn't like ALICE due to she is over powered (than there favorite character I guess).

B. Eugeo:

Eugeo is my second favorite in SAO: Alicization he is innocent, kind, loving, caring, spirited and great swords man as Kirito who fight for good. The biggest fact in Eugeo is, he has complete sense of humanity.


5. Enjoyment:

About enjoyment it is more enjoyably season then the previous seasons because it has cliffhanger in "every episode" which is not there before!



6 Overall:

10/10 as a gamer, a programmer and an anime lover!

SAO: Alicization (or SAO season 3), started with a right foot on first few episodes.  And we all fall for this marketing hook, SAO mid season become so boring to watch it is dreadfull even to waste your time on this anime... Really just don't watch it, mark my words!!! You won't regret it, as I did.
I am 27 years old man, and I would even dare to say, that even teenagers would not enjoy SAO... It's totally garbage, when you make all 50 episodes about climbing a single 100 floor tower, which what this anime is all about... Kirito has become a child...Srsly he is now a child... It's like Watching Dragon Ball Z, later you think Dragon Ball GT will be even better, but you understand that MC Goku transformed from adult into a child... Which is so lame to watch, this series are hitting pit bottom really soon among mid-old audiences...


Don't get me totally wrong here, that I am a hater or anything like that, I enjoyed season 1 and Gun Gale Online too, they were kind of ok'ish to watch. Introducing a fairy AI was like Jar Jar Binks in Star wars, and the MC villain just - well lets just say he didn't had any emotions or strong motivation to build SAO in first place, which kind of makes him dull and very easy to forget, that this guy even existed... And Gun Gale Online, didn't had anything I didn't like, but Gun Gale was a bit too late to release its series and didn't bring anything new on TV table at that moment for audiences to watch and consume...


Story: 50 episodes about 100th floor tower gets 1/10


Why so low you ask? Well, when fighting is happening between 4  grey walls, in closed space, and I mean majority of battles is in closed space. There is no beautiful places, only grey walls in the background. Producers and authors were very lazy on season 3, It cannot even be compared to season 1. The first few episodes of season 3 were kind of interesting, as they were introducing new concepts, but when you put a few drops of honey on a pile of sh*t, it doesn't make it sweeter... And this tower climbing never ends, like the Ancient Greek legend Sisyphus, never ending rolling to the mountain. Plot becomes really obvious, even if you didn;t read LN. And Kirito's goal of this anime become not saving his life like in the first episodes he concluded, but to save all this non existing Virtual world without any'ish casualties... 


Art gets 5/10

Art is very hard concept to discuss, so I will just skip it and say its average, it's what the least quality you would expect from famously titled SAO


Sound 2/10

They were kind of good on first episodes, where was the most interesting part of season 3. But later you become too much familiar to the same sounds, so they kind of becoming a part of the problem - they are becoming boring to listen and I believe they are taken from older seasons like season 1  or 2.


Character 1/10 there are only 2 MC here Kirito and Eugeo: 


Kirito becomes a child, he even acts like a child sometimes, especially naive, even though he is almost 30 years old!?! Really creators??? It's so unnatural instead of becoming older to become younger... If old man becomes a child, he would still act as an old man, he wouldn't disregard his life experiences and seriousness... 


Eugeo, well he is like a Pinocchio, he decided to become a real human being... Well I kind of understand now, why author would create an AI fairy cheater in season 1, so they could turn Eugeo into a real boy in season 3...  And its not a spoiler, it's totally my speculation...


What is sad to watch, that Kiritos friends aren't with him in this season too. Even his wife, maybe will join him on last episodes of season 3, but I was expecting her to join way sooner, instead she is chilling drinking tea with science team, while Kirito is barely winning his fights, and because he is saving the world without any casualties, he simply cannot die or get injured enough to abandon this naive childish thinking of saving the world thingy. This world doesn't even exist in a first place, and new thousands of worlds could be destroyed and recreated in different computers at the same time... So really Kirito should focus on his ,god dammit, - life saving goal and get out of this world ASAP, before he gets killed or perishes together with the world... 


Enjoyment: 1/10

You will enjoy first few episodes, but after that you will feel hoaxed, and drop this crap like I did, there are way bigger fishes to watch in this huge Earth of ours...


Overall: 2/10

Don't watch it, its a trap! You will regret latter if you do!!! Don't say I didn't warn you


What else you could watch besides SAO? Gen:Lock, Shield Hero. Cya ;)

Sword Art Online Alicization is 4-cour.... That's right, 4-cour. Instead of adapting an a terrible show, "They" decided to take this more seriously. SAO Alicization being 4-cour means there will be less time skip and quality world-building. Not only that, it is likely that the story of the show will be given more focus or else a 4-cour adaptation wouldn't be necessary.
With that in mind, I speculate that it's going to be better than the other seasons of SAO. Though I haven't finished the whole thing yet, the first cour makes it seems promising.
------(Some Spoilers Ahead)------
First Cour Review
Story (7/10)
The story-telling is great. It's more in-depth,and there's a reason for events instead of using plot convenience, so it felt more enjoyable. Focus is put onto world-building in the first few episode but there's also action, they managed to put together the first few episode in a constructive manner, explaining the world to the audience without Kirito being all-knowing while delivering sufficient action to capture the audience's attention. 


Kirito is given 2 years to train, and he didn't actually become immortal plot armor god through that. He is still weak even after that and have to retreat in some of the fights.


Art and Animation (9/10)

The animation is very high quality, especially during fight scenes. The color is vibrant and gives a fantasy vibes to the show


Sound (7/10)

The Opening songs is great as usual since it is sang by LISA, it is memorable and decent.


The Ending song is also quite good. The songs feel sad and memorable.


Character (6/10)

This time around, there's no harem for Kirito.... I know, sounds impossible but it happened. Kirito instead is partnered with Eugeo, a male character with a lot more screen time than Klein and actual character development. There's even a girl that fell for Eugeo. Yes... A girl fell for someone else other than Kirito.


Kirito also have a slight bit of character development, though a very small amount currently.


Overall = 7.2/10

Here's my review, all memes aside.
I never thought SAO was incredible, and i never thought it was terrible either, but I did think it was enjoyable and kinda fun to watch, and as guy who's into light novels, and has read the entire alicization arc, i can say this is by far the most SAO season/arc.
However
the anime hasn't done it justice so far. The pacing is too fast, you meet characters that you start to end up caring about in the light novel, but in the anime its just like "HEY, heres some characters you'll see for 2-3 episodes and NEVER see again!", and Ihate being the guy thats always like "the books better than the movies!" but I am quite disappointed the adaptation, but yet I'm still enjoying it, even with the changes they've made.\n\n
If you never liked SAO then you won't like this. If you do like SAO, or maybe you liked the first season and never watched anymore, then you'll probably like this.

This is the best SAO ever, I'd say. Much better than the other seasons. The art style and sound effects are amazing. A-1 Pictures definitely worked hard on this. And I can see that the original novels are trying something different from the previous ones. But it is not perfect and has many flaws. The characters are literally just plot devices. And some of the settings don't make sense. And Asuna!!! Her screentime!!! 
      Overall, I'd give this show a 7. I will keep on watching it. If you want to check outthis show, go watch it, it's great, but don't expect it to be a masterpiece.

Like others, comparing SAO seasons, I too say this one is probably the best... As of the most current episode, 10, to this review. 
Main reasons why I like this season the most: 
- Kirito finally has a close male friend that we see with him at all times and is separated from his harem
- holy shit there's so much blood... Well, at least in that one episode, and I love it because to me, it just adds more flavour to this anime and creates the setting of how the rest of it may be
Of course, since the beginning, SAO has shown what kind ofanime they'll be and how their characters, good/bad, will be portrayed, meaning, their personalities will be overemphasized immediately. The 2 main villains thus far are extremely exaggerated, but it still made me hate them with a burning passion, and yet very satisfied when justice was served in this messy way. I personally like how Eugeo's character is developing. We all know how Kirito is, and how OP he may become despite starting from beginning stages of the game and still managing to defeat higher level combatants. I like how Kirito is mentoring Eugeo in swordsmanship and morality. It's more like this season is about Eugeo rather than Kirito, which I'd prefer as Kirito has become the master several times already. \n\n
Some things I disliked:\n
- the main characters do feel a bit bland, probably due to the time skips so we don't see the actual progression in themselves and relations with new characters (the new characters pretty much just appear without intro)\n
- the main villains so far are extremely exaggerated, also the personalities of others like Volo or later Alice, but then again, this is anime so, it's to be expected... But I still won't prefer it (however, the moment Volo smiled after the exam duel, I was very happy seeing more than just stern and angry faced Volo)\n
- Kirito's line about having more confidence in your whatever that powers your internal strength/will, will amplify the power to your sword (I just find this very cliche or even cheesy, but it has been similarly like this for other SAO seasons)\n\n
In the end, I'm gonna be entertained and likely satisfied with the remainder of the season. So far now, up to episode 10, I like it.

Ok, I am a person who usually defended SAO when people claimed that the story, characters and everything else was poor after the first 12 episodes of 1st season. I sort of enjoyed the story behind gun gale and movies (well, it didn't blow my mind or anything, but it was decent for some anime&popcorn evenings) But this series?! Oh my [insert something vulgar] ! From the very beginning of this season I kept telling myself that this show can eventually get better. That something will change. Guess what, apart from 2 maybe 3 scenes throughout the 24 episodes the story development is getting evenmore boring. 70% of a time Eugeo appears as a dumb sidekick whom I could only compare to the Mud from the game called Gothic. The things that happen to the characters are in my opinion poorly explained, and the whole tower rush is so prolonged and silly, that i had to drink a lot of coffee not to fall asleep while watching it. In my opinion this is the worst SAO show so far, but judging by its rating, I guess it also found some enthusiasts, so maybe I am just getting to old :/ \n
Anyway, if you didn't like the show after first few episodes, don't fool yourself. It doesn't get better :(

Alicization. SAO III. Whatever you want. It's actually not that bad.
Story: This season of SAO is more focused on developing and fleshing out certain parts in the story, rather than having a condensed and rushed version of the source material. This helps it in the long run, allowing for scenes to actually have impact on the story and characters to be developed. However, what this show lacks is that certain aspects of the story that were introduced at the beginning of the show or middle don't seem to carry the relevancy they could have had when getting to the end of the show. For example,our favorite Umu girl, Cardinal, is introduced in the middle of the show, but by the end, becomes irrelevant with her powers by the end. I'm trying not to spoil, but you get the idea. The story itself in this show is much better told than the first 2 seasons, however. I will say that the end of episodes do keep you on the edge, which is always nice assuming that you're invested.


Art: The art in this season is a major upgrade from the previous seasons. Shading is done way better, and scenes pop out in color. The battle scenes in the first half to the final of the show are really nicely done (even if Admin feels much different), and everyone's special abilities pop out in how different they are. With the art, I have no actual qualms.


Sound: What can I say? Music is nice, character voice acting is well done. Clown boi is creepy like he should be, Eugeo's voice drops as he becomes more and more confident in himself, etc. Everything works as it should.


Character: Oh boy, this is where it gets a little rough. I do like the improvement that they did in character development, since everyone gets a little something. Kirito uses his intuitive mind and his experience to get through the Underworld skillfully in a way that doesn't seem like complete BS, which always helps the story not feel rushed. Eugeo's character arc is pretty much throughout the entire show, where he slowly gains confidence in himself, then realizes that what he's fighting for isn't for himself. Out of everyone in the show, Eugeo becomes the most likable by the end, even with that one part that I can't talk about. Even still, certain developments in the story are explained with backstory that gives us an actual reason as to why characters do what they do, and that can't be said for certain parts of previous seasons. Aside from the main cast, the side characters do get some development, but not much. In fact, I wish that they would have delved deeper into some of the characters with the time they had. The trainees, Tiese and Ronnie, I would say, are the only exception. They had their arc with Lord Raios, but they also were given backstories that shape their character development, and don't remain static characters. With certain others, such as Kirito and Eugeo's mentors, could have been developed further. With the relationship between the 4, I feel that the setup would have prompted more development between the mentors, but that is one part that's lacking from the show. Sortiliena is an interesting character with an interesting backstory, but that's wasted on progressing the training montage with Kirito and his fights. Speaking of that, the guy he fights with doesn't really get much character for the first "villain" of the show. However, overall, with the main characters, this season is definitely the best we've gotten, although I feel the first season did the minor characters better.


Enjoyment: Despite the stigma against SAO, this season was solid and held its ground. It had shaky moments, but those were smaller parts within episodes that could easily be remedied by good ol' plot development. Even if side characters could have been developed more, that didn't affect the overall story. In all, I feel that this is a nice season of a show in general, but a great step in the right direction for SAO. It's like Ordinal Scale all over again.


Overall: Did this season live up to the expectations? Yes and no. The show did well in story when compared to the other seasons, and is a good contender when compared against the best out of all SAO, Ordinal Scale. However, it did lack certain developments of characters that could have been fleshed out even more. Does it deserve the hate that's automatically given due to the name, like GGO Alternative? No, absolutely not. However, what you give this series as a whole, judging by the content alone, is entirely up to you. If you've watched one season of SAO, I recommend this season. If you haven't touched SAO, then this season is still a good watch, but based on the base material needed to understand this season, it'd be a decision that I can't justify nor retract a claim for watching or not. Overall verdict? It's pretty good.

After three series with Kirito, I might be done. The most painful thing about Alicization is that it started off somewhat strong with an interesting idea, but then dissolved into a lot of the same problems I've had in the past:
- The villains are poorly written and their motivations are always clear but never well explained.
- If there is a male villain, there seems to be this tendency for the author to go far overboard with their villainy. I don't know if the author has ever noticed subtleties in good villainous characters. 
- Female characters will show strength at times, and then suddenly abandon itto suddenly become an emotional, vulnerable puddle for Kirito to "fix".\n\n
A-1 Pictures did an amazing job visually. It's gorgeous, for the most part. I'm not sure if they were involved in the decisions behind episode 10, but my opinion of them would drop if they were the ones to decide to include such a depraved plot device rather than change it for something (almost anything, really) better. \n\n
I was skipping up to 3 minutes of an episode due to so much useless and boring exposition that offered little to bite into. That's the worst thing: this season has many moments that leave me outright disinterested. Kirito didn't see any development we haven't seen before, so this leaves a lot of focus on some of the new characters and the plot. When I say "focus", it's more a lack of focus. When your plot includes graphic assault of multiple characters, at least have the decency to keep those characters around to develop them more. Instead, it's all focus on the plot and "technology". It's insulting to the audience and the characters to have these moments that are supposed to absolutely huge and devastating emotionally, only to realize they were simply there to get Characters A and B to Location D.\n\n
The author of this series continues to learn very little about what issues there have been previously. The future of SAO looks grim, full of exposition and very little care for character development or plot-pacing. If you like SAO as it is and always has been, the future looks plenty bright for staying the course, keep the status quo, etc.

It's nice to see all the armchair "experts" who bullied kids away from the first two seasons coming back to explain us how one of the most successful anime of the century is actually poorly written, boring, and a threat to world peace.
Luckily, I am no expert at anything: I can freely judge anime by how much I like them, instead of forcing myself to find stuff I don't understand and call it "poor writing".
If you liked the first season (and the second too, but you're too scared of the bullies to say it), you'll probably like Alicization. It weirded me out for a coupleepisodes, because it wasn't at all what I expected (what did I expect? Dunno, but having watched "Alice and Zoroku" I was probably looking for a more Alice-y, erm, thing); then it grew on me. It's NOT Sword Art Online: it's a different story with different characters, and it uses SAO as sort of a stepping stone. Because the nth isekai anime would probably be ignored if it wasn't a -supposed- sequel to the one that sold the genre to the general public. \n
So, is Alicization any good? Well, I like it. Does it have the same issues SAO had? Don't know, ask the armchair bullies: to me, SAO didn't have any particular defect (insert mouth frothing and cries of RAPE! INCEST! here). Is it entertaining? Yes, definitely.\n\n
• Story: big initial surprise, some meh moments followed, then the story starts and it's good. Unexpected. The "real life" parts are useless and just an excuse for pretending it's "SAO". Fortunately, until now, there's been a negligible amount of them. 8/10\n
• Art: what do you expect, it's SAO. I sort of didn't love the movie, but here the original top polished, perfectly animated art is back. 8/10\n
• Sound: ditto. Not as bombastic as the movie: just the right amount of beautiful audio scenery and character. 8/10\n
• Character: as in "characters"? Good good people, bad bad people, generic generic people; nothing to say - I guess the action puts all these standard personalities in the right place. 7/10\n
• Enjoyment: yes. I'm always expecting the next episode, even when the current one isn't "great". I find myself wishing for a faster pace, and at the same time wanting a 365-episodes anime. You know, like Bleach, but with an actual story. 8/10\n
• Overall: if you hated SAO, or you were bullied into hating it, don't fret: this isn't SAO, you have my permission to watch it XD. If you liked SAO, well, this is an isekai anime with cute characters, awesome fights, a little introspection (sadly, much less serious themes than in SAO), stupidly good art and sound, and a compelling story. Like it! 8/10\n\n
Why isn't this a 10/10? Don't be silly, I've given less than that to some Miyazaki stuff.\n
Why not a 9/10? Because it isn't revolutionary, nor surprising, nor shocking enough to deserve an almost-masterpiece score. It's honestly "Very Good", nothing less, nothing more.

I am kind of busy lately so I can't really afford to follow the unspoken rule of 3 episodes before deciding with every show this season so I exceptionally checked reviews before watching the shows this season, the top reviews almost convinced me to not watch this season, but thank god I didn't trust them.
Story:
if you are unfamiliar with SAO then you should really not start SAO with Alicization, if you are, well there is nothing to add to the synopsis without spoiling. It is a story in a fantasy virtual world which is what you would expect from SAO, this time it looks likeKirito has to risk his life again to protect the virtual world and its population.


Art: 

It is not something unique, but it is gorgeous. thus the 9/10 and not a perfect 10.


Sound:

can't wait for the official release of SAO Alicization OST. great OST implemented perfectly, nothing to complain about here.


Character:

While Kirito did not change much compared to previous seasons, his companion, Eugeo, has gone through a lot of development, the other named characters are all unique and interesting. Some has just had a portion of their generic backstory shared to justify their actions which is better than nothing indeed but does not suffice.

characters are not outstanding as some other shows but good enough to not make the show enjoyable.


enjoyment:

a perfect 10, started the show when there were about 12 episodes aired and I caught up the next day, fight scenes are not long but smoothly animated to make you enjoy every second of it, the OST as I already said is great (including in battle scenes), the rest of the time is spent explaining important things, developing the characters and building up for later events/revelations.


overall:

9/10, I have only been praising SAO so far (and no I am not an SAO fanboy) but I understand why some people may not, if you enjoyed the previous seasons/movie  then this one will not disappoint, if on the other hand, you hated all of SAO, you are better off skipping this one as well. Personally I never really loved SAO after the first arc of the first season, but I am enjoying Alicization even more.

SAO has always been one of my favorite animes of all time. I hold this anime to a very high standard and because of that, I decided to hold off on watching week to week at first so I could get a proper binge watch in for the first 15 episodes. I watch a lot of anime but SAO, in particular, is an anime that I expect to affect me in a totally different way than other shows. I expect this show to hit me emotionally, please me with visually striking images, and to provide excellent soundtrack music during its airtime. So far, this showhas done everything that I have expected (with some minor hiccups here and there.)


First off, I basically love this anime and everything about it. I think the show's art is only matched (and beaten) by Violet Evergarden in terms of aesthetic and overall production value. There is a very clear difference from SAO 1 & 2 and Alicization in terms of this. The sound design is flawless, with each clash of the sword sounding more epic than the other. The voice acting is stunning as well. I would like to praise the Eugeo voice actor for demonstrating considerable range and depth as the show has progressed. The fights here are more plentiful and just as stunning as those that happened in previous seasons. It's as if the developers said to themselves "The name of our show is Sword Art so we're going to make sword art truly amazing." Each fight is epic and carries with it the same emotional weight as the Gleam Eyes fight in SAO 1. 


A lot of this show screams that the producers looked at what made SAO great and just emphasized this going forward. Kirito's character is also very much refined and matured from the first couple of seasons. He actually gets beaten up a lot and requires help in the majority of his fights. While I never really cared that he won all of his matches, I know a huge criticism against him was that he was too perfect. Actually, Kirito makes A LOT of mistakes in this show and is constantly on the losing end of things as he tries to make sense of this new world. 


I cannot emphasize further on how excellent the fights are. They are easily some of the best pieces of work that I have seen in an anime ever. There is so much to love here, truly. 


***SPOILERS BELOW****


While there is so much that is great about this anime, there are some things that have rubbed me the wrong way or just not worked for me. I should first admit that these are things that generally have not ruined the anime for me and can be fixed by the conclusion of the season. Firstly, as emotional as the show is, it still hasn't struck my emotional cord as much as the previous seasons have. I feel 'slightly' less invested emotionally than I have so far now 19 episodes in. This season is going to be 50 episodes so there is room to change this. I believe they should work Asuna into the plot more to get more emotional involvement. Also, being 50 episodes and having just experienced a filler episode, I can't help but think that there will be more down the pipe. A part of me thinks that they extended their episode count beyond the amount of source material they have. 


While these are things that have me concerned but can be fixed with future episodes, there are also a few things that just rubbed me the wrong way. I am talking about the rape episode in particular and a few other things. I know Sword Art has a history of rape themes throughout but I wasn't expecting an entire episode to be devoted to a bloody and disgusting rape scene that left me feeling sick where I did not enjoy a single second of it. Alicization to me is supposed to be a refinement and mastery of what people love about SAO. To make an entire episode devoted to rape was just a huge turnoff for me. I also have not enjoyed the filler episode as well as the two episodes that involved the Cardinal where she explained back story. The Asuna plotline is razor thin and has provided nothing but wasted time. There is so much to love about this show and I hope to see less of these negative elements in future episodes to come. 


P.S. Don't really like that little dwarf minion guy that froze Bercouli I can just tell he will bring nothing interesting to SAO.

Honestly I started this anime with really high expectations because I was told that this season will be the best one so far. So far, that statement is entirely false. This anime is by far the most inconsistent show I have ever saw. Most of the time if a show is bad, it stays bad all the way and good show stays good all the way. However this anime is good sometimes and boring as hell for the most of the time. 
Story: 7/10 
At this very moment I cannot judge the story because nothing really significant happened in this show. This is also thedownfall of this anime. Hopefully the story will finally pickup at some point.   


Art 10/10:


The art is simply very pleasing to look at and I have no complaints. 


Sound 8/10: 


There are no bad songs that I recall. However the openings are good.


Characters 6/10: 


Some of the side characters seem bland and uninspired. And most of the main cast tend to act cool or edgy most of the time. The characters in this anime seem very simple, cliche and overdone to the point where they do not feel special or human in any way. In other terms, the good guy are the most good of good to have ever gooded the land and the bad guys are the baddest of the bad and they will ALWAYS do bad things because they are bad.  


Enjoyment 7/10: 


This anime is still very enjoyable mostly because of the flashy colors. However that is ruined by the fact that this anime is the most inconsistent piece of garbage you will ever experience. One episode can be simply amazing and the other would be a bunch of characters sitting their moving their lips of 20 minutes talking about a plot point that I don't care about. Also, can we not put scenes of the outside world in the show, that kinda ruined the mystery of the why Burito is in a video game. 


Overall 7/10: This show has some flaws but its still good. Hopefully the many problems in this anime will be fixed in the future.

SAO is a good anime.. we know it.. but it's not a perfect anime either.... with SAO releasing its third installment the hype and good animation is there, but after watching the episodes more longer it gives you the feeling of dragging or we call it slow development, i know we need more story and not feel rushed like the First season. but WTH man there's a big jump in time like almost 1 or 2 years i think the time we lost that could have been great story background for kirito and his yellow clone to have character developement, but all we get issome Rich guy bullying some girls and kirito on the rescue plot. there's a big hole and its not an excuse for the story to drag. \n\n
PLus well this is not really a big spoiler. our plot is that we got Aincrad a big world type tower setup for season one and now we got Church Tower type setup which is a big downgrade to me and i will predict that the last 10 episodes will be focused on that same tower which is very boring....

Unrelated to the Gun Gale Online spinoff, this season of SAO continues the main story line right after the Death Gun incident from the second season. There appears to be some new VR Full Dive technology around and it would seem that despite his traumatizing experiences with it, Kirito's interest to check it out is no less than what it was before. SAO: Alicization, as its prequels, establishes a strong setting with unfortunately lacking authenticity in the character department. Connoisseurs of existentialist themes and philosophy revolving around life and death will again enjoy this. However, be warned that the characters are not written to bevery believable and some previous tropes (power tripping, greed) are being rehashed without much novelty. My enjoyment in this I can attribute mostly to the fact that I am a sucker for existentialist themes, which are being established well in the first half of the show. If you disliked the prequels however, you will also dislike this.

tl;dr The concepts are awesome, as usual coming from the mangaka, but the story directing and character dialog is terrible.
Really, he's exploring whole new ideas about immersion into technology and virtual worlds. It's awesome. But that's all there is to it. And shiny fights, and the usual dramatic tear draining music and scenes. But those are generic to any anime that uses them.
How the characters behave and talk to each other is ridiculously bad. Like a novice wrote the dialogues. And the slow boring drawn out pace it's presented makes it even worse.
The whole show could have been like 3 or 4 episodes without thelame stuff. And it would have been awesome.

Oh god is this boring. For a series that was viewed for bad character development and relied on good art and better fight scenes this is less exciting then watching paint dry. Its pretty that's the most praise I will ever give it. Its an action anime right? Then why are most fight scenes of people standing still and just swinging their swords twice. Yelling and good music can only go so far when all I see on screen is a guy holding a sword NOT MOVING for almost an entire minute. 
This should of been a revival of Kirito with a new interesting storybut instead it becomes a lackluster friend adventure due to terrible fight scenes and never ending cringy dialog.

I don't really get the hate Alicization is getting, if you didn't like this then you must have hated season 2 because this is much better.
This season started being rated over an 8 but now is around 7.5, so I'm guessing most people thought the 1st half of the show is better than the 2nd and I agree mostly. There are some boring moments and it kinda drags on for a while but the action is intense and the animation is beautiful. the ending is also beautiful and gives a good cliffhanger for the next season. 
I thought this anime was well done and worthwatching the 24 episodes. Sword Art Online sometimes has a little too much dialog and not enough action but I think Alicization is a good mix of both, could probably still use a little more action for my taste. I've been giving out a lot of 8s lately because that's just where I am with most new anime I've been watching, there's a lot of good shows airing but nothing that I would say is a masterpiece including this so another 8 here.

I really like this anime, or at least the first half of it.
However towards the end, especially the last 3 episode, the series resorted to the worst SAO could unsuprisingly bring.
From setting up harem expansion to the pure invincibility of Kirito, only Kirito.
That's not much of a spoiler of course, neither should it be when i tell you the only people getting killed are those with decent worlbuilding... Be it for no reason, like a voluntary sacrifice that would achieve nothing anyway, or a death that could not only be prevented, but which kirito, to be honest, was so eager to accept.
This series rocked,
Just dontwatch anything past episode ~20, That's where series shit the bed.

This show was good but wished it had a bit more spunk. Was still thirsty for more but hoping the second part does it justice. Was great seeing new fresh characters from the app game im playing into here, since i had no clue who or where they were from.
The story was nice, then stale, then a huge WUT??! moment, then good. And the "villians" were pretty unique, each offering a different power and way of thinking which granted them there strength. 
Really wished some fights were longer, they didn't do justice do those "OP" characters at all. Other than that it was a goodride. \n
Also be prepared for a very harsh moment, depending on your standards it can be tough to watch or just another Tuesday for you.

A little summary of what I think of SAO in general. Somewhat liked the first 7 or so eps of season 1,but  hated rest of season 1 and the entirety of season 2. I had very little expectation going into Alicization but I decided to give it a chance after reading that it was the best arc. I will definitely agree that it is the best SAO arc by far.
Story: 8/10.  Much, much better than the previous arcs. That said, there still are writing issues, most of which stem from the author's tendency to portray Kirito as the overpowered, perfect harem master. Thankfullythis time, there is a second protagonist, Eugeo to save the day. More on this later. 


Another big improvement over the previous arcs is the stakes. After the first arc, it was really hard to care about anything going on because in the end, this is about some kids playing a stupid video game. This time, however, I cared. The virtual AI's have feelings, hopes, and dreams just like real humans do. Even though the setting is a virtual world, the anime does an excellent job of making it feel real in an organic way. 


Art: 6/10. It could have been great, but it's meh. The character designs look good, but that's where the pros end. There are frequent animation errors and serious blips in the presentation (especially pronounced during some action sequences). If you liked the Light Novel style illustrations, you won't find it here by the way; the art style is quite different.


Sound: 9/10. Great.


Character: 9/10. Huge improvement. Eugeo is well written. He actually has flaws and believable motivations. He develops as a character throughout the story. I also liked the way they wrote Alice, the main girl of this arc. She's not just caught and imprisoned in a cage sucking her thumb like Asuna did in arc 2, nor is she useless/boring like all the other heroines. Moreover, the main villain is WORLDS ahead of Kayaba or the other villains whose names I didn't bother to remember. The extra characters felt fresh and intriguing as well, which is a first for the series. The only cons come from it being... SAO. Kirito is still boring and previous girls (Asuna included) are useless.


Enjoyment: 10/10. Because of the massively improved writing and characters, in addition to the plethora episodes the animators have to work with, I enjoyed the anime immensely. I hope this continues into future cours.


To sum it up, if you absolutely hated all of SAO, this probably won't interest you. But if you saw potential in the early episodes of SAO, I would recommend this series. It's what SAO should have been from the beginning.

Being a fan of all the previous ones I hoped to see amazing battles with an overpowered MC who always beats the odds.
In the previous ones the movements were amazing and the skills used made a lot of sense from the point of view of someone who has spent a lot of hours playing MMOs; in this one... well all of that is lost.
The skills don't make sense, the explanations are ... passable at best, the character grow is because of the power of plot and the time-skip makes everything even worse.
Will keep watching til the end because of the subplot but I don't expectall that much.\n\n
Clearly the worst of all SAOs.

As a fan of other SAO animes this one is by far the worst one. You can watch this by watching every 3 episodes and you wouldn't miss anything. Storytelling is very slow, boring and repetitive. In Dragon ball they are fighting for 5 episodes but here they are repeating thing that you as watcher already know for 3 episodes. Five episodes of any decent anime have more action and character development then this anime has in 19.
Even tho we see Kirito again he is nearly completely disconnected from older plot so much that they are building him agen (as character) even tho you knoweverything about him and his personality. \n\n
Only good thing i found in this anime were fight animations. They are spotless and very well created but they dont get nearly as much screen time as they should for anime that is listed as: "Action, Game, Adventure". Whole anime feels more like random guy inside game and he is trying to do good thing while falling in love then what we expected from anime taged as "Action, Adventure".

A caution, very gentle spoilers lay within this body of work, but I can only recommend you watch this show if you are the type who is driven by morbid curiousity, some sort of Anime Stockholm Syndrome for the franchise or you wish to engage in a highly elaborate form of masochism from tedium.
You have been warned.
If you have not done so already, I would suggest you read George Orwell's classic dystopic fiction novel, '1984' and imagine that the only detail they really got wrong was that in the penultimate chapter it was not rats that finally broke the will of the protagonist; it wasforced viewing of SAO 3.  My laptop became my room 101. 


Okay, so to actually explain the previous paragraph, I used to say always that SAO was never as bad as people made it out to be and really had one serious problem above all others: Needs less Kirito and more of... literally any other character. Any of them. But this new series, promised to be the best yet in fact, instead does in spades what every critic has always accused the series of... in spades.


All the supporting characters, especially Asuna, are fairly compelling but instead we are feed Mr Bland, Mr OP 'Beater' Kirito till we are filled from gullet to arsehole. 


But here we are, in the year of Our Lord 2026, and what do we have? More Kirito. In fact, he is the most Kirito he has ever been. The most powerful and the most bland. And look, another virtual game that he is instantly lord and master of. Yay. 

But wait, now he has Eugenio too, who while fairly bland himself, has at least a little character. In the final tally counts well against him as his sole character trait is, he's a total bitch. A complete and total bitch. In a just universe, he would be made to cut that tree till the heat death of the universe, that is the only lot such a pathetic do-nothing should have in life.


There is some sort of... plot about... Kirito being assaulted, put into a coma, linked into a highly ascended nerve gear machine by his workplace at the behest of the Japanese government where they create copies of the human psyche using only the finest psuedo-science. But really... I mean, who cares? 


It's Kirito.


There could be some sort of moral conumdrum about the value of the reasearch such an endeavour would produce versus the life and dignity of a human or at what point are these ersatz-psyches enough to be considered real people? 


But it's Kirito. We don't care about Kirito. We can't care about Kirito. Not any more than we could care for a throw-rug or cardboard box. He is chattle, literally a piece of cheap, digitally rendered chattle. A disposable man for a disposable art. 


The biggest weakness of SAO has always been Kirito, and now we are being given yet another goddamn double-cour, or maybe more, helping of Kirito. Bland all the way through. He is so generic among shounen protagonists in that he is the MOST generic among shounen protagonists. There is no character here and a shounen anime is nothing but a character story.


This is perhaps why Gun Gale Online Alternative was so well recieved, despite having the Link Start albatross hung about it's neck. 


The art and animation are really pretty weak too, the alicization stuff is dishwater-strength fantasy anime design and the other stuff is what it always was. I feel there has been a real step down in character design. But that's just puppet strings and they would vanish from view if the sins of boring character and story were corrected.


Overall, while I have nothing positive to say about the show I will say it did allow me to finally give up my constant, near-decade defense of the frachise. It's quite liberating really.


So, congratulations A1, you did it lads. I, a staunch former SAO apologist have finally decided; I love big brother... and I hate Sword Art Online.

Beats the GGO crap, but not quite season one.
There were some profound insights. But I feel the pressure of PC culture crushing the potential. And here "Reki Kawahara to Write More Politically Correct Stories Due to Western Pressure" I already feel it seeping in in this season. But one of the best parts of the story was Eugeo and Kirito fighting Religious totalitarianism and getting justice for the assault of their students. 
And now he plans to "not use sexual assault as a plot device". Newsflash. Highlighting hard and painful issues in anime IS the right thing to do, and anime has been the oneplatform able to pursue this and talk about hard subjects freely without media suppression. \n\n
But Reki is giving in to the western so called "liberal" iron hand. \n\n
This will be my last SAO.

Oh boi, it's a Sword Art Online
So unlike many others, I've actually generally enjoyed the Sword Art Online series. I really liked the Sword Art Online arc of the first season (like many others) and was a little less impressed with the Alfheim Online arc... but I still enjoyed the the adventure even if I had some grievances. I actually really enjoyed the Gun Gale Online arc and Mother's Rosario of the second season. Mind you I did sorely miss a fantasy setting. 
I thought that Alicization would be something I really like with it going back to a fantasy world. Sadly I was leftwith a lot of very hollow feelings. 


Art: The visuals of the show are pretty sub standard even for A-1 pictures. There's nothing here to write home about. The visuals are clean and neat but the characters all really kind of look the same honestly and the background are dull. It's like Kirito and Blonde Kirito are off on an adventure through halls and stairways. The background and settings do little to excite the imagination. 


Story & Characters: There was some potential in all of this. Actually I'd say the story is pretty decent, it just suffers because of lack of stakes or impact. Kirito is poisoned and so he gets experimental treatment in a full dive system. Asuna is worried and clearly untrusting of the company doing the treatment. The real world aspect at the beginning of the season is arguably some of the more interesting stuff. 


That said once it flips to Kirito's side of the story inside Underworld that's where it really kind of weakens. The world just feels flat, the characters that Kirito meets are new AI's meant to mimic humans who grow up and live lives no different then any other human to be honest. That said it is hard to get into a story with these new characters. Simply put we are told to get invested, and there's an artificial sense of bond we are supposed to feel between Kirito and these AI's but it didn't resonate at all with me. 


Simply put I did not care about Eugio or Alice as characters, and that made it really hard to get into the story. I didn't even sincerely believe Kirito's bond with them. It made it hard to feel anything towards them. It's sad because this isn't even a new topic for SAO. Season one had Yui, an AI that Kirito and Asuna adopt, and I honestly got more of a connection from those characters. 


So when the whole story is that Kirito and Eugio want to save Alice... and that's the only motivation for everything, it felt really hollow. I mean Kirito doesn't even seem to be driven to figure out a way to get out of this new VR game. Honestly the stakes on paper look high, but in reality what is really at stake? We aren't told what happens if Kirito dies in the game. Does he die in real life? It's a very convincing VR world, but he's not strapped into headset that can fry his brain. This is kind of the core problem of the story. There's this gap between the initial tension of the start of the season, and the new problems introduced within the virtual world. 


The two problems never even really intersect or acknowledge one another. So the conflict within the game takes precedence. It's here that you have a competent story. There's a very clear cut goal, and quest to be had with obstacles to overcome to reach that goal, and it's all handled nicely. It's just that it doesn't line up with other established things. 


It doesn't help that the rules of Underworld are incredibly loose and a lot is left unexplained. Also of all the VR worlds, this one feels the least like it's VR. Save for the occasional menu pop up and mention of admins and stuff, you'd think it was a generic fantasy anime. 


And that's the real problem with this newest season of SAO. If it wasn't for the brand name tied to this story, it would be incredibly generic and mediocre fantasy anime. It barely feels like I'm watching an SAO story unfold. 


It's just a generic fantasy anime with Kirito a character I became invested in over the years so now I want to see what happens next. Mind you nothing really happens that feels worth while till the final two episodes. 


Sound: honestly the music was largely forgettable. I don't remember much from it and nothing stood out. There wasn't anything ear grating, but nothing you will find gets stuck in your head. 

___________________________________


The Bottom Line: 


It feels like an empty hollowed out version of SAO. Honestly people like to hate on SAO for things like an OP main character, and some harem tendencies, but those first two seasons were still entertaining and compelling adventures. People did really get on board with the story for a reason. 


That said Alicization is kind of a dull story feeling like a husk of what people enjoyed about the first season. I feel like even fans of the series might be left disappointed by this one. I never considered the first season a master piece but I at least had a lot of fun and enjoyed the characters and the premise even with their miss steps. 


If you didn't like the first two seasons, I have a hard time believing there is something here you will find enjoyment in. I don't know where the story goes next. I'll check it out because I'm invested, but honestly this season felt overly long and drawn out with little reason to keep watching.

I am disappointed .... really disappointed ....
I heard that this arc was japanese fan's favorite, so I was having some hope for it but ... Whether japanese fan have no taste, or the adaptation is really bad. But in any way this is clearly not good.
I was a great fan of SAO, I started it when the first season came out and it was really enjoyable, there were always ups and downs in the arcs but it was still fun, until this season. 
I don't even understant why this season is called "Sword art online" there is no frikking reason for that except to keepthe old fans of SAO. This story coul have been the same with other character, no need to use our overpowered Kazuto to be the hero again ....\n
But well, let's focus on the main problem here: the Story. There is so many plot hole in it that I want to call it: Sword art Online: Gruyere. Note: Spoilers for the anime and the LNs.
There are plenty of reviews judging this anime by its own merits. This is not one of them. I have read the SAO Light Novels ever since 2012, after the anime aired and was promptly barraged by criticism. To be perfectly honest, I have not watched the anime until recently, and when I did I could see why it was so hated. Even so, I loved the LNs and I was happy with Ordinal Scale, cheesy romance movie as it was, and I hoped Alicization would finally dial down the hate for SAO. 
Story: 6/10
Alicization's story delves intothe question of the human mind, and what it means to be human. Sure the technobabble is bullshit, but it's not like Hollywood science does it any better. That said, the anime's plot is incomprehensible at times, and I mostly blame it on the ehh adaptation. 


For example, for all the IMAGINATION POWERUP comments this show has, it's true that this game messes with your mind in a way The Seed games don't. It's why Kirito comments that it is indistinguishable from the real world - the STL system supplies the basic information, and your mind supplies the rest (details, graphics, sensation of pain, gravity etc.) Given the nature of this system, "believe hard enough and the system thinks it's real" doesn't seem so bullshit. It explains why after his Dive, Kirito had some difficulty readjusting to the real world, and it is probably why he reached out for his sword when he was attacked in episode 1, to cite an example.


Just for viewers to understand that, Kirito would have to monologue enough to break A-1's bank on VA fees alone. Of course, a lot of it is skipped in the anime. And there are many, many more like it - not only plot elements, but also character development. For what the anime accomplished with its storytelling, which if nothing else did an adequate job of going from one plot point to another, I give it a 6. 


Characters: 3/10

The worst aspect of the adaptation by far. To explain, let me describe the main characters as I understood them before the anime: 


- Kirito: A pitiful person. He understands his parents are not his real parents, and doesn't expect them to care for him beyond the most basic necessities. He knows his parents love him, but feels guilty because he feels a disconnect with them. He secretly looks down on other boys his age because he thinks they are childish, so he has no male friends. Even so, he craves company and the feeling of being needed. Eugeo was his first male friend and first student, and once everything was over, he wanted to take Eugeo out of Underworld, make him log on to ALO and show him off to his other friends. 


- Eugeo: He comes from a family of farmers and it was expected that he would become one. His family was disappointed when he became a woodcutter. As farming became harder because of natural disasters, his family depended on his wages, but they did not like that they had to depend on him and did not treat him well. His only friends were Kirito and Alice, because the other boys were jealous that he caught the attention of the cutest girl in town. After Alice was gone and Kirito left, nobody wanted to come near him, and they thought he deserved what he got. He understood that, and was resigned to it for the rest of his life. 


- Thirty: She felt like a fake borrowing the body of Alice Zuberg, betrayed the system she believed in, and suffered pain intense enough to burn and explode her right eye for it. Not much else needed to be said. She knew that Eugeo wanted Zuberg back and accepted that she would have to die, but requested to be able to see her sister one last time, after all of this was over. Kirito understood that she was a victim and wanted to save her, even though he knew Eugeo only wanted his Alice.


Because he was desperate for any love, Eugeo fell for Quinella's trap. Because Kirito wanted to save Knight Alice and Eugeo did not, they would have to fight. Because Cardinal (the sub-process) took over Quinella when she was in distress and tried to commit suicide with her body multiple times, Quinella deleted her own emotions. Because Quinella still could not go against what her parents taught her and break an oath, she would have let the trio go. To the average watcher, none of the characters made any sense. 


That said, bonus points for suffering Kirito. Ever since the original SAO, for all the Jesus-kun the anime made him out to be, this has been Kirito Suffers: The Series, and I'm glad people are catching on to that.


Art: 8/10

The quality took a noticeable downturn in the last few episodes, but the art and action more or less look beautiful. Could afford to dial down on the filters and CGs, though they were not enough to bother me until the last episodes. 


Sound: 9/10

SWORDLAND HYPE.  Nothing else to be said about Kajiura music. OPs and EDs were stunning, and the mad men reanimated the OP to show later fights. Voice acting work was beautiful, and if you got to watch Yoshitsugu wailing Nobunaga's name, while the latter runs around flapping his arms trying to get someone to notice him in the after-episode 24 stream, you could see why. The VA work makes the scenes at times. 


Enjoyment and overall: 6/10

Nice quality, hype music, action sometimes. I have an understanding of why plot moves the way it does, even if it's not explained in the show. I have seen worse anime than SAO, and I was equally happy and frustrated with it. A solid 6.

But the story and character development are jokes. Whoever pacing the story musthave not read the novel before, cutting things out and expecting viewers to understand. WHY I LIKED:
⬤ Mesmerizing high-budget visuals
⬤ Asuna-Free + Yui-Free SAO (Not a necessity but definitely feels comforting)
⬤ Nerfed Kirito (for the most part...)
⬤ SAO finally manages to build up a world properly before jumping to next arc
⬤ Smooth and creative swordplay (for the first half..)
⬤ Gorier and darker. (Lots of pain, blood and dismemberments)
⬤ OP for the first half is amazing. I am still listening to it from time to time.
WHY I DISLIKED:
⬤ Most of what I said above was for the first half.
⬤ Lots of bromance and very little room for choreography.
⬤ The plot left the server as soon as they set foot onthe stairs. The show becomes Bruce Lee's Game of death for next ~10 episodes. Same setting over and over, made up bosses with very little to no background\n
⬤ Same old SAO. Towards the end all we have left is a nerfed Villain and plain characters with empty motivational speeches. Per usual Kirito is waiting for someone to suffer fatal injuries, so he can send condolences, soak up their power, steal the spotlight, grunt and moan as he wishes until the Villain dies\n\n
SUMMARY:\n
Its a good thing SAO is learning from mistakes but the change is too little and the show wasnt beyond my expectations.\n
Aside from improved visuals, nothing is notable.\n
Well I cannot blame them so easily, the plot to start with was a wreck.\n
Except for Cardinal none of supporting characters is worth mentioning or remembering.\n\n
Again, I might sound too desperate and bashing. I remind you that I evaluated SAO: Alicization based on SAO and 2019 standards.\n
Just like Kazuma said to Darkness: "...all I could see in you were your boobs. You are boobs. Boobs"; "...all I could see in this show was pile of graphics. The show is pile of graphics."\n
Under these circumstances I cant see myself giving an average SAO more than a relieving [[7/10]] !\n\n
Story: 5/10\n
Art: 9/10\n
Sound: 7/10\n
Character: 4/10\n
Enjoyment: 6/10\n\n
Overall: 7/10

The entire season I was on guard hoping that the rumors I heard about Alicization would truly have it be (quite literally) the redemption arc that the series needed.  The moment I let my guard down, the moment I do, that's when I'm reminded "Oh right, this is SAO" and it fucks up again.  Come on, why is this the thing you're consistent about?
Story:
Following the events of Mother's Rosario, Alicization takes a different turn to seasons prior where this time, Kazuto finds himself helping out with a research project involving 'Fluctlights', artificial human souls that were created via digital means.  After an extremely unfortunate incident(that really shouldn't have happened), Kazuto is put on life support and is thrown into a new VR world called the 'Underworld', where he alongside a Fluctlight in the system named Eugeo hope to rescue a girl from their past named Alice who was taken away by the powers that be that govern the Underworld.


First and foremost, the story of Alicization's first half spans the entirety of the series's runtime, being given ample runtime to fill in the cracks and let the story mature and progress at its own pace.  Because of this, any previous problems with the series rushing are pretty much mute since so much of the Underworld and how this VR reality is run is explained and talked about with great detail.  In a sense, Alicization doesn't really feel like SAO because so many of its narrative elements are given time to mature, the massive power fantasy with its protagonist is muted down to be almost equal with his cohorts, asspulls are saved only for the end (I'll get to that one...), and the rules of the world are so grounded and consistent that I found myself consistently accepting what was going on and actually was very intrigued by what would happen next given the fact that the build up of the entire series was so well done and reminded me of when I was super engrossed in the series watching Season 1 for the first time.


However nothing good can last forever, and the unfortunate reality that this was still part of the SAO series reared its ugly head and put all of the work and effort to make the story not terrible into the trash because fuck you.  Both the ending and final encounter with the antagonist of the series are AWFUL.  It feels like Kawahara Reki just didn't know what to fucking do to cap off this first half so they just went "GIANT SWORDS" and called it a day and capped everything off with a massive cliffhanger in order to ensure people will continue watching despite the fact that's just a nail in the coffin for me to expect the worst to come given how confusing and messy the ending is.  I am genuinely disappointed (and sad) about how this section of Alicization ended because they had something REALLY good.  For once the story didn't fuck itself so hard, characters were interesting, and the world was really cool, but NO, you can't go one fucking section of this story without throwing caution to the wind and do not just one stupid thing, but multiple in quick succession because sure, why not I guess.


Characters:


Kazuto (because I hate calling him Kirito) is probably the most not protagonist protagonist he's been since Mother's Rosario.  While he largely still doesn't seem to possess any noticeable character traits for himself beyond being the 'amazing protagonist' that reaches for the goal at hand while caring for his friends (you know, generic shit), it'd be wrong for me to say that he doesn't at least improve as a character.  Since the series this time doesn't put him on a massive pedestal where he's the virtual gaming god that literally hacks the system and gathers bitches from all four corners of the VR world, what we get is a more subdued and supportive version of him where he's more trying to back those around him and let their character shine through his help.  It's a nice change of pace because it gave a chance for everyone around him to shine while keeping him relevant enough for his presence to matter.  To me, this is the right balance for him.


Next is Eugeo, Kazuto's partner this time around and probably the most conflicting character the series has made thus far.  A largely timid boy who looks up to Kazuto for strength and guidance, what annoys me about Eugeo is how he doesn't for the most part have agency of his actions, relying so much on Kazuto and Alice for any 'approval' of his actions.  That's not to say that he doesn't have some spectacular moments to himself.  With all of the stupid things he does in this series, he conversely has a number of really choice character moments that balance out this weird dichotomy that the series is trying to achieve with him.  I'm not particularly a fan of how they ended up doing his character, (especially given that clusterfuck of an ending), but in the long run it's at least something worth noting.


Then there's Alice, the sort of 'endgoal' girl that makes up the motivation for our protagonists' actions.  If you ask me, there's nothing bad with Alice's character.  Though she has arguably the least amount of screentime of the three protagonists, she by far has the most impactful use of her appearances due to the whole 'knight rebellion' thing she has going on, especially when everything she's doing is in response to how everything in the Underworld works/is run.  It's a culmination of everything that the worldbuilding/series has done up this point with the setting, and that to me is probably the best thing this season has done in terms of good character.


Real world people hardly matter beyond exposition, so bye Asuna and your dwindling relevance in this story.  To make up for that, the residents of the Underworld take on a medieval/European aesthetic with everything from farmers, to knights, to the oppressive church that governs over everything using both faith and an ironclad law to make sure the populace obeys the rules lest they get whisked away in chains.  Aside from the Pontifex who is an interesting mix of sociopathic tendencies and god complex (with really shitty plans and a disappointing end), the cast largely falls on continuously building on the world by adding characters like snobby nobles, sword senpais, the blacksmith, knights without their memory, and whatever else you can throw in to make the overall world and narrative that much more interesting since they all culminate into Alice's character and the protagonists' motivations, which work towards the series' favor.


Aesthetics:


Pretty sure A-1's budget for the year was spent on this show.  Alicization is undoubtedly beautiful, taking the quality and art of what the production studio achieved in Ordinal Scale and turning THAT into the anime adaptation.  Flashy effects, fluid animation, gorgeous art, beautiful scenery, and little to no consistency errors, I could go on and on about just how good the art for Alicization is.  Hell, even the CG doesn't even look that bad.  I mean it's noticeable, but the shading and modeling of the damned things look like they fit with the show.


One point of questioning I have for abec and by extension the art team at A-1 is why the Pontifex is like...always naked.  Like that's a nice dress, why'd you basically dissolve it and make her fight the protags with nothing but her birthday suit?  Like I get she's mentally insane with dwindling RAM space, but my god, is fanservice really the only reason why this is a consistent thing for the last what, 6 episodes?


If I had to choose a favorite, I'd say that LiSa's "ADAMAS" is my favorite of the two OPs.  ASCA's "RESISTER" is good and all, but you can't go wrong with another song made by the woman who made Crossing Field one of the most recognizable songs in the span of modern anime.  Both of these song are extremely high energy and give off that fantasy feel, but I just personally think that ADAMAS, with the drop that it has is just superior.  That being said, they're both great songs, and I'm glad that the new tracks for SAO keep the same quality as the others before it.  In contrast, both Eir Aoi's "Iris" and ReoNa's "forget-me-not" follow the typical SAO song scheme of being more muted and less energy than their OP counterparts.  I prefer forget-me-not to Iris personally, but I find them less memorable by comparison.  (Also Yuki Kajiura comes back to compose the OST and oh my god Sacred Swords is a good remix.)


Final Thoughts:


For all the crap that I really want to give for SAO fucking itself over again with such a shitty ending to this first half of Alicization, I can't deny that this is DEFINITELY a step up from what we ended up getting from GGO (which yes, is the last time that Kazuto was properly in the spotlight).  Everything from the pacing, the characters, and the overall writing made it feel worth it to say that I'm watching SAO again unironically.


Eugeo might not be as good as a coinciding protagonist that I initially wanted him to be, but Alice more than enough picked up his slack and became so much better than I expected for being the character that was supposed to first be the 'damsel in distress'.  That being said, the ending is still stupid and I seriously have no idea what the fuck they were thinking when they ultimately unveiled everything because all the build up got torn right the fuck down, why is there giant swords, what's the motivation for sacrificing yourself, the Pontifex's plan is stupid, I don't care if you're voiced by the Maaya Sakamoto, this is on par with the stupid shit that happened in Fairy dance.


While bracing for disappointment is ultimately what I have to say about Alicization (Part 1 apparently) in the end, I'd be remised if I didn't once again comment on just how good the build up is this time, especially in comparison to the rest of the series since it felt like the season this time had the time to really make the story happen instead of just let the plot run by.  I just hope that by the time Alicization 2 comes around, we get an apology for this climax.  Cause man, that was bad.

I'm going to skip straight to "How To Watch" because this season's quality greatly varies by episode.
How To Watch:  The first four episodes felt like a return to form for the Sword Art Online series.  The story was interesting, it had an intriguing air to it, the characters showed promise.  I can recommend watching, but absolutely hard stopping at 4.  After that, you are warned.  The flaws of the previous seasons come creeping back then slap you in the face.  Unnecessary, slow drama ruins the pacing.  Hateable yet untouchable antagonists make the show difficult to watch.  Bythe time I saw a Content Warning on episode 10, I knew I had to give up.  SAO is still SAO, a beautiful concept that, in execution, is the opposite of fun to watch.

Sword Art Online: Alicization is (as you may have already heard) a massive step up from previous seasons though to be fair that really doesn't say much. 
It's simply a basic fantasy-ish sci/fi-ish isekai-y show that we've come to expect from sword art though it has made three major changes to sword art fundamentals that make it so much better.
Firstly the fanservice is gone. Now I can appreciate some good fanservice as much as the next guy but the overabundance of it in previous seasons I think we can all agree detracted from the quality of the show as a whole. Though this is theleast of the three problems it is nice to see that they put some thought into how to retain audience attention instead of just shoving T&A in our face constantly.


Secondly the side-characters. Apart from one episode focused kind of around them and maybe two other scenes the side characters (bar Asuna) are completely ignored and the show is all the better for it. Honestly, the only reason I remember some of the side characters exist is that of the abridged. Though to be fair to those who do like such memorable characters as "token black guy" and "oh yeah his sister hung around after the second arc" these characters do get there an episode of glory before promptly being ignored for the rest of the season (so far).


Thirdly and finally the main character. Time to talk about the elephant in the room, the biggest problem with the first two seasons, Kirito. In seasons one and two Kirito was a boring cardboard cutout who was overpowered when he logically shouldn't be. In Alicization Kirito is still a boring cardboard cutout but he's no longer (as) overpowered and they add another character in Eugeo, though he's by no means a complicated character he is far better than Kirito as a character and an audience insert, make no mistakes Kirito is still our lead and is still a bad character but Eugeo makes him just that little bit more bearable.


To conclude Sword Art Online: Alicization realized the faults of what came before it and is attempting to build itself into a better show by changing the core problems of it, while I would prefer if the series went full SAOAGGO I can still respect what it's doing to reinvent itself. Does this mean it's a good show? No, it still has its flaws but I do now have hope that this series could one day become something that lives up to the title of #3 (at time of writing) show by popularity on this website.
