Sincerely, Kawahara was one shitty writer long time ago when he published SAO, but somehow it was made into relatively good anime series.
It hadn't had any pacing, story was nonexistent, it was all about just waifus and there wasn't much plot, yet somehow they was able to produce an enjoyable thing.
They're basically rewritten the entire thing, adding some logical links that should be there (but was never actually thought by the author), paced it anddirected it into one good show.


Why, for the love of god, why couldn't they make at least something not horrible when they had one of the latest Kawahara's stories? Kawahara honed his writing skill for decades, finally making something with good setting, with story, plot and pacing all included, with characters instead of placeholders this time and with reason instead of waifu hunt.

All they needed to do this time is to just not fuck up.

Yet they fucked up royally.


Honestly, I had very little hope after the season II and that shitty spinoff.

Yet, when I saw the budget, some hope was resurrected inside me.

Sadly, only to be raped and slain mercilessly.


=====


I don't want to go deep into details on this one, I'll just point few moments and I promise that these are the best moments and everything else is just boring and doesn't worth your time.


Moment #1:

So we have this relatively decently directed PVM scene where one of two main characters got seriously injured and at this point combat scene just stops so they can have their moment of yaoi. This moment is minute long! The fucking whole minute (that is more than enough to rip those kids to shreds during their sudden homosexual stroke) bad guys just stand still and watch them talking to each other.

Martial arts choreography is already shitty at this moment.


Moment #2:

10 minutes long rape scene with two girls tied up. Bad guys spent 10 minutes demonstrably spreading girls legs, yet we haven't saw a single pantsu nor a single nipple. Why was that scene had to take 10 minutes instead of one second? Probably for that we can be sure that this series is far beyond point of no return.

Death scene later in that episode contained a lot of ad-libbing bullshit. Probably to double confirm passing the point of no return.


Moment #3:

Not really a moment, but rather a long standing tendency: there's a lot of info dumps where there was none in the novel (including some accidental major plot distortions just because someone was too lazy to either actually read the novel or to just ask the author), while also some big and meaningful chunks of story are just skipped. Those info dumps wouldn't be needed if only we had the story.

But, I guess, it's much easier to draw just a talking heads than to draw an anime.

Sadly, when in the novel we have a story about a character and then we have a plot twist so we can feel emotions, in here we are just being told the end result without any reason given for us to care.


Moment #4:

A lot of screen time for naked woman who looks and moves surprisingly similar to Yuuki Asuna while having nothing to do with her.

Firstly, it's one very cheap trick to beg for higher ratings.

Secondly, she looks and moves like Asuna probably because character design was too expensive.

Lastly, not a single nipple nor anything was shown despite exposing completely naked female person for more screen time than I can count.

What was the point of her being naked?

If not service, then why couldn't we have this scene shown in just ten minutes instead of SIX FUCKING EPISODES, so we can have at least a few episodes for some story (which is available in abundance in the novel, but I guess we are not worthy to see it animated)?


Moment #5:

Amount of minor plot fuck-ups hides the fact that there actually is very good, detailed, structured and well developed interesting multilayered plot in this story.

It actually feels like someone deliberately sabotaged it.

I can't believe such amount and such magnitude of fuck-ups is even possible.

So this is gonna be My first review... I'm English person and don't grammar well. Also warning on any possible spoiling.
So I enjoyed character Eugeo, and that was about it, the main problem I had was how... quick and abrupt it ends, that's why my opinion is low for this branch of SAO. Now back to another part on why i somewhat enjoyed was surprisingly the intro song, and end? (Have watched anime, but still don't know this). They just felt right to me at least, I don't really know why either. The fight scenes to me felt really 'special', except one of them, whichI'm not going to name. The fights though they were quick in a sense felt fluid, and thought through. \n\n
Even I may find that the overall may be good, certain part left a bad taste in my mind; Which makes my decision teeter towards less-favorable of my anime list.

The anime started off pretty well. I thought it was somewhat of an interesting concept, had a little bit of mystery to it and the art was good.
However, after the plot was explained, it seemed like the entire thing slowly fell apart. They act like there is some sort of 'danger' but then seconds later everything is perfectly fine for the main characters. Everything always seems to work out perfectly in the end, which, especially in this anime, is absolute nonsense.
It feels like the anime makes less sense with each episode you watch.
Besides that, the dialogue is HORRENDOUS. I have literally never seen such poordialogue that made as little sense in those last few episodes... apart from in Glasslip [don't watch it].


The longer the anime goes on, the sloppier the animation gets as well. Apart from the last episode, which was better. The sound effects [which I usually don't really take into account] seem to pretty samey.


All in all, I literally skipped through the last episode because I just couldn't stand to watch this any longer. It didn't make me feel anything, I felt completely detached from the entire anime at the end.


Makes me feel really bad for all the hard work the animators, voice actors etc went through when the plot was just... pretty bad. Or, just badly executed.


Anyway, not really worth your time.

My only problem with Alicization is that the anime is just so poorly made. I am a SAO fan since the beginning, and the Chinese community(which is my community)have a generally positive attitude towards SAO, so I never found any problems with it. I've seen the mangas, I've read the novels, and I have to admit; the Alicization novel is a masterpiece. We all know that the author of SAO wrote the first few novels to win a competition, and due to the length requirement, there was not much detail description or character developments. He wrote the Alicization novel years later with obviously better writingand anyone who've seen it will call it a masterpiece even they did not like the series. All the problems with the anime is never a problem in the novel. The pacing feels great, and the story is comparable to the good stories such as Erase(which I just watched a few days ago). The character development and etc are amazing, you just can't find much fault with it. But the anime was a mess, I did not enjoy it as much as the novel AT ALL. It has the same problems as The Rising of the Shield Hero, which I've also read the novel, the first few episodes are amazing. Especially the hour-long first episode for both. But as the story advances obvious mistakes were made. Such as characters out of shape or bad(and often) scene divisions. The Scene divisions is a total mess and the fighting quality drops, etc. The thrill the novel can give me never occurs a single bit in the anime. For people who think the anime is bad, you are correct but do not forget that the story itself has no fault with it. A-1 once again ruined a masterpiece. Congrads.

Sword Art Online: Alicization is what happens when a show opens with all the signs of something good, then falls flat on its own face. Rather than getting up, dusting itself off, and trying again, SAO: A goes the route of Gen I Magikarp and chooses to flop around uselessly for the rest of its run, both embarrassing its viewers and the person too proud to admit despite its overall value in its evolution, it's a pretty shitty Pokemon. Well, Fisher Bob, your Magikarp sucks, and you do, too.

You good? Okay. 



The series opens up with Kirito hanging with a couple new friends, a blonde clone of himself named Eugeo; and, a blonde-haired girl named Alice (who may or may not be a copy of Asuna. Jury is still out). After an adventure to a cave to look for ice (one of many poorly-researched topics, and the least-egregious in the series), the trio get lost and witness a dragon-riding knight fighting another dragon-riding knight. The evil(?) knight is knocked from his stead, causing Alice to stumble forward a few steps towards the threshold of the cave and outside into the no-go zone. She trips and falls, her fingertips barely over the threshold. 


In this world, walking into the darklands(?) is forbidden. This child barely had her fingertips over the threshold, and that was by accident. All good, right? Just tell God you didn't mean to and it'll be fine, right? 


Nope! God decides "welp, that little girl is a heretic! Better send my inquisition to chain her up and make an example of her!" So, this guy called an "Integrity Knight" drops by the village next day, calls Alice to be arrested, and shenanigans ensue. A few moments later, LOLI'S WITH GUNS GUIZ LOL. The shows goes from interesting premise to everyone messing with a supposed PK'ing clan in GGO because Shino asked them for help. After that insanity, Kirito explains how he has no recollection of events in the Underworld (where we started from). Interesting premise. 


And then Fluctlights. 


Let me explain this in a way that Reki Kawahara fails miserably at doing. In SAO:A, the Japanese government believes "fluctlights" are basically the soul, and it's located in the brain. Their intent is to create artificial fluctlights so that war doesn't need to be waged with living people anymore. No, let's create artificial people who are unaware of the nature of their existence, so that we can wage war in video games. Hey, guys, PLANETSIDE 2 EXISTS AND HAS DONE NOTHING TO DETER TERRORISTS AND OTHER WARMONGERING GROUPS FROM STICKING TO RL WAR. Oh, but they thought ahead. Mass-produced artificial bodies for the fluctlights. That's right, son! You can build your own waifu, or put your existing waifu into an artificial body, forever robbing her of the illusion of self-determination and causing her to experience an endless existential crisis after removing her from the setting and events that ultimately shaped her being!


So, anyways, Kirito and Asuna are walking, Kirito gets REKT by some nerd with a needle because he forgot he's not an irl samurai, and ends up hospitalized. EXCEPT, in the infinite wisdom of the Japanese government in the SAO-verse, they kidnap him and continue the fluctlight experiment. He appears to Eugeo, both their memories gone. He helps Eugeo cut down the giant uncuttable tree so Eugeo can change his calling, the two go to the capital to become Integrity Knights, Eugeo auditions for Thor or Big Boss, Kirito kills a man (seriously, blood and all), both are arrested, and then decide "lol screw the system". They fight some Integrity Knights who are actually the Underworld's famous historical figures with their memories altered towards Piety for the world's "God" Administrator, decide that Administrator is garbage and it's time to hack the website and dethrone the admin, get into some shenanigans, a loli hugs Kirito, Kirito and Eugeo get paralyzed and dragged around by loli's, Kirito cuts said loli's, they meet notAlice, and then Eugeo becomes an Integrity Knight but doesn't, a loli dies, Kirito saves the day, except he doesn't because brain damage. 


Now, the issues. 


Fluctlights. Fine concept, poor execution. What should have been a series about a man trapped in a game that is actually "medieval lifestyle simulator 2022" with existential ponderings about the nature of the soul and how one could go about replicating it (and really, if it ought to even be attempted), is instead just another miserable attempt to inject "depth" in an otherwise bland, uninspired isekai. This could have been the entire premise for a first cour that demanded the viewer to ask some rather meaningful questions about a concept that is probably bs, but demands the same amount of consideration as GiTS does with its esoteric content. If fluctlights can be manipulated and transferred to another body, how does that change the nature of our world? Who is artificial, and who is real? It's a great concept which, unfortunately, gets mentioned as an excuse to have a macguffin, and never brought up again. 


The setting is easily one of the most interesting in concept. Putting aside the generic medieval concept for a second, you have a world where magic isn't just in existence, but is several lines of code that the people are unconsciously aware of. They perform the "Arts" by accessing menus that require an input before appearing, etc. It's an interesting concept, and one that, again, is unfortunately put aside in favor of bland fights and poor exposition. 


And finally, the characters. Kirito is less OP, but still manages to cock-block his new harem. Eugeo is basically Kirito except more subsmissive and less powerful, which could be neat if he had any character to begin with. Alice is... eh. Her character is a plot device in the beginning, and, when the Integrity Knight version of her appears, it's an under-developed mess that goes from "DEUS VULT" to "lol screw the church". This also applies to the Integrity Knights who, to our knowledge, are supposedly the supermen and women of the world, but end up as one-off jobbers to Kirito and Eugeo. Hell, in perhaps the worst display of misogyny in the SAO-verse, one of the IK's is only a knight because she has a crush on a dude. I kid you not, her entire purpose for fighting is to get laid. Fuck. Reki. 


Unfortunately, the end-boss is nothing worth mentioning. Administrator is an over-the-top laughable villain whose pseudo-intellectual banter with Kirito amounts to the following:


A: What is man, but a miserable pile of secrets? 


K: A living, breathing organism with the right to choose! If you are God, then I will hath none of ye!


A: But, does God not exist to ye, as well? Then, what is your self-determination, if not the guidance of that uncaring, unloving entity?


K: Aghast! I am confounded by your ability to undermine my self-determination at a basic, grade-school level, as though I've never experienced these existential concerns myself! I am at a loss for words for your wit!


A: Ah-ha! I have taken it upon myself to recognize the hypocrisy of your actions, in opposing my will as "God" when my understanding is determined by the limitations of my own creators! Truly, I am superior, since I have bested ye!


In conclusion, what is life? SAO:A doesn't know, and makes no attempt at even presenting a position. It wants to present neat concepts before devolving into its purposeless fight scenes and mindless drivel all to drive the plot forward. Unfortunately, it crashes right from the start and never recovers.

Now, I actually really liked the first 2 seasons (gave it a 9 and 8) Gun Gale: Alternate was also pretty good at an 8, the movie was alright with a 7, but this... oh boy I'm so bored with this series already
I feel like the story is all over the place with LOADS of exposition randomly thrown in half way into, before and after battles. The battles are also quite terrible, there's no real swordplay involved, just 2 people playing with Star Wars lightsabers clashing swords for half the battle then one uses a skill, gets blocked then mc uses skill and wins... (plotarmour OP) where's all the fancy choreography? I don't know why I've watched it for this long, I might drop it soon
